math_problem.A3921:
Denote by $\mathbb{N}$ the set of all positive integers. Find all functions $f:\mathbb{N}\rightarrow \mathbb{N}$ such that for all positive integers $m$ and $n$, the integer $f(m)+f(n)-mn$ is nonzero and divides $mf(m)+nf(n)$.

[i]

math_problem.A4050:
Does there exist a sequence $ F(1), F(2), F(3), \ldots$ of non-negative integers that simultaneously satisfies the following three conditions?

[b](a)[/b] Each of the integers $ 0, 1, 2, \ldots$ occurs in the sequence.
[b](b)[/b] Each positive integer occurs in the sequence infinitely often.
[b](c)[/b] For any $ n \geq 2,$
\[ F(F(n^{163})) \equal{} F(F(n)) \plus{} F(F(361)).
\]

{
  "reasoning": "Problem 1: We seek f: N -> N with the property that for all positive integers m,n, the integer D = f(m)+f(n)-mn is nonzero and divides mf(m)+nf(n).\n1) Plug m=n: then 2f(n)-n^2 ≠ 0 and divides 2n f(n). From this, 2f(n)-n^2 divides n^3 as well (by taking a suitable linear combination), so 2f(n)-n^2 is a divisor of n^3. This gives a rough growth control on f(n).\n2) Plug m=n=1 to get 2f(1)-1 divides 2f(1). Hence 2f(1)-1 divides their difference 1, so 2f(1)-1 = 1, giving f(1)=1.\n3) Now set m=1 and general n. With f(1)=1, we have d_n = 1+f(n)-n ≠ 0 dividing 1+n f(n). From the combination n d_n - (1+n f(n)) we deduce that d_n also divides n^2 - n + 1, hence |1+f(n)-n| ≤ n^2 - n + 1, which keeps f(n) within a quadratic range.\n4) Check small n explicitly using the divisibility constraints: for n=2 and m=1, the condition forces f(2) to be 4 (other candidates lead to D=0 or violate divisibility). Similarly, consistency of the conditions for pairs (1,3), (2,3), (3,3) restricts f(3) to 9, and proceeding inductively with (1,n), (2,n), (n,n) etc. shows that for each n the only value compatible with all divisibility conditions is f(n)=n^2.\n5) To see there are no other solutions of the form n^2 plus a constant, try f(n)=n^2+c. Then D = m^2+n^2-mn+2c and mf(m)+nf(n) = m^3+n^3+c(m+n) = (m+n)(m^2-mn+n^2+c). For this to hold for all m,n, D must divide (m+n)(m^2-mn+n^2+c) for all m,n, which reduces (by taking linear combinations and using m=n) to the requirement that m^2+2c divides 2m^3+2cm for all m. This in turn implies m^2+2c divides 2mc for arbitrarily large m, impossible unless c=0. Similar tests for multiplicative scalings f(n)=k n^2 give a contradiction unless k=1.\n6) Conversely, f(n)=n^2 satisfies the requirement: f(m)+f(n)-mn = m^2+n^2-mn, and mf(m)+nf(n) = m^3+n^3 = (m+n)(m^2-mn+n^2), so the divisor condition holds and D>0 for all m,n.\nThus the only function is f(n)=n^2 for all positive integers n.\n\nProblem 2: We need a sequence F(0),F(1),F(2),... of nonnegative integers (we can harmlessly extend to index 0 to make F(F(·)) always meaningful) satisfying:\n(a) each integer 0,1,2,... appears at least once;\n(b) each positive integer appears infinitely often;\n(c) for all n ≥ 2, F(F(n^{163})) = F(F(n)) + F(F(361)).\nLet G(n) = F(F(n)) and let C = G(361). The condition is G(n^{163}) = G(n) + C for all n≥2.\n1) Look at the mapping n ↦ n^{163} on the set of nonnegative integers. It partitions the set into disjoint orbits of the form {a, a^{163}, a^{163^2}, ...} for those a which are not themselves 163rd powers (plus the fixed-point orbits {0} and {1}). Within a given orbit O, the equation relates only consecutive elements: for n in O, both n and n^{163} lie in O.\n2) If we choose C=0, the equation becomes G(n^{163}) = G(n) for all n≥2, i.e. G is constant along each orbit. Conversely, if G is constant on every orbit and C=G(361), then automatically G(n^{163})-G(n)=0 for all n≥2, so consistency forces C = 0, i.e. G(361)=0.\n3) To build such a G and corresponding F, proceed as follows:\n   - Partition N₀ into orbits under n ↦ n^{163}. Label them O_0, O_1, O_2, ... and ensure 361 belongs to some O_j.\n   - Define a map r from the set of orbits to N₀, and then define F so that for every n in orbit O_i we set F(n) = r(i). This makes F constant on each orbit.\n   - Then G(n) = F(F(n)) = F(r(i)), which depends only on the orbit index i, so G is constant on each orbit. Hence the functional equation holds with C=0 provided that G(361)=0.\n4) To ensure G(361)=0, let 361 ∈ O_j and pick r(j) to be some number a. Then G(361) = F(a). Now choose the orbit of a, say O_k, and set r(k)=0; then F(a)=0, so G(361)=0 and thus C=0 as required.\n5) Finally, arrange (a) and (b). For each nonnegative integer t, assign r(i)=t for infinitely many distinct orbits O_i. Because each orbit is infinite, the value t then appears as F(n) for infinitely many n (all n in those orbits). In particular, 0 appears (from orbits with r(i)=0), and every positive integer appears infinitely many times. This choice of r also respects the special choices for the orbits containing 361 and its image a.\nThis construction yields a sequence F of nonnegative integers satisfying all three conditions, so such a sequence does exist.",
  "answer_1": "f(n)=n^2 for all positive integers n",
  "answer_2": "Yes"
}
output_answer: f(n)=n^2 for all positive integers n
